required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Quality of Life and Personality Traits in Patients With Type 1 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Quality of Life and Personality Traits in Patients With Type 1 Diabetes

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Medicine

clinical_study.source: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The aims of this study are to examine the differences in the quality of life among individuals with type 1 diabetes and individuals without chronic diseases, differences in the quality of life among men and women with type 1 diabetes and the differences in the quality of life among individuals with good and poor glycaemic control. The relationship between personality traits and the management of disease in patients with type 1 diabetes will also be examined.

detailed_description.textblock:
Diabetes affects the daily life of patients, chronic diseases have a major impact on the quality of life of individuals. Chronic illness affects family life of an individual, his professional life, as well as leisure activities, chronic illness can also increase worries, fears, feelings of sadness and helplessness.
Past studies examining the quality of life construct in patients with type 1 diabetes (T1D) showed that patients achieved lower levels of life quality, compared to individuals without T1D. Studies show that women with T1D achieve lower scores on the quality of life scales than men with T1D and differences in gender are already present in adolescence.
Patients with poor glycaemic control achieve lower results on the quality of life scales, the effect of hemoglobin on the quality of life is direct, as well as indirect.
The studies in which they examined the attitudes of personality traits with diabetes management show that two personality traits are associated with the management of the disease, the successful management of the disease is primarily associated with the conscientiousness. Concerning the effect of neuroticism on the management of the disease, research results are contradictory.

primary_outcome.description: Differences in quality of life in patients with T1D and individuals without chronic diseases. Quality of life will be measured with the WHOQOL-BREF quality of life assessment tool (questionnaire).

primary_outcome.measure: Personality traits associated with diabetes management
primary_outcome.description: Which personality traits are associated with good and poor diabetes management. Personality traits will be measured with The Big Five Inventory questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in quality of life based on gender
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in quality of life between men and women with T1D. Quality of life will be measured with the WHOQOL-BREF quality of life assessment tool (questionnaire).

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in quality of life based on glycaemic control
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in quality of life between patients with good and bad glycaemic control. Quality of life will be measured with the WHOQOL-BREF quality of life assessment tool (questionnaire). Glycaemic control will be reported from participants (HbA1c).

arm_group.description: Young adults (male and female) between the ages of 18 and 35, who have type 1 diabetes for at least one year.
Young adults (male and female) between the ages of 18 and 35, without chronic diseases.

intervention.intervention_name: The World Health Organization Quality of Life (WHOQOL) -BREF
intervention.description: The WHOQOL-BREF instrument comprises 26 items, which measure the following broad domains: physical health, psychological health, social relationships, and environment.

intervention.intervention_name: The Satisfaction With Life Scale - SWLS
intervention.description: The SWLS is a short 5-item instrument designed to measure global cognitive judgments of satisfaction with one's life.

intervention.intervention_name: Big Five Inventory - BFI; John in Srivastava, 1999
intervention.description: The Big Five Inventory (BFI) is a self-report inventory designed to measure the Big Five dimensions.

study_pop.textblock: Young adults of 18 to 35 years of age with type 1 diabetes and young adults of 18 to 35 years of age without chronic diseases.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age between 18 and 35
- Diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes for at least one year (for the T1D group)
- Willing to participate in study
Exclusion Criteria:

facility.name: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Arts, Department of psychology
